sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: This is Euronews Tonight. Here are your top stories.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Russia says at least 40 Ukrainian prisoners were killed in a blast, with each side accusing the other of shelling a prison camp in separatist held Donetsk. Eurozone inflation hits a new record, but economic growth also proves more robust than expected. Plus, preparing for a winter without Russian gas, German cities impose cold showers and switch off the lights in public buildings, all in a bid to save energy. And here in the Cube, we'll unpack the fall from grace of a Spanish body positivity campaign.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: I'm Helena Humphrey. Glad you could join me. Moscow has accused Ukraine of killing dozens of its own soldiers in a missile strike on a prisoner of war camp in the Russian-controlled Donetsk region. But Kyiv denies any involvement in the attack, instead blaming Moscow for the blast.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Our reporter Glynis Crook has more.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: The Russian army has accused Kyiv of organising an attack on a jail in the separatist-held Donetsk region.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Moscow says the facility was housing Ukrainian soldiers, including Azov fighters, and that 40 prisoners were killed and more than 75 wounded.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: The Ukrainian army says it never conducted strikes on civilian infrastructures or prisoners of war.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: At the moment, a large number of Ukrainian servicemen voluntarily lay down their arms, knowing about the humane attitude towards prisoners of war on the Russian side this blatant provocation is designed to intimidate Ukrainian servicemen the circumstances of this provocation are now being investigated in other news Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky has

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: visited the Black Sea port of Edessa. He's overseeing the first grain export from the country since they signed a joint UN-Turkey broker deal with Russia.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: The first ship is being loaded since the start of the war.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: This is a Turkish ship.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: I'm standing with this ship in the background.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: That means the port has started operation.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: The main thing for us is the port is working, the people are working.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Meanwhile, heavy bombing has destroyed a public transport stop in Mykolaiv, killing at least five people and injuring seven others.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Glynis Kruk, Euronews.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Well, for more analysis now, we can bring in Samuel Romani, Associate Fellow at the Royal United Services Institute, joining us from Oxford in the UK.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Welcome to you, Samuel. Great to have you with us.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: In light of this blast which we have seen...

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Oh, he's back.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: In light of this blast that we have seen in Donetsk, Samuel, Ukraine's new prosecutor general says that he'll be opening an investigation, a war crimes investigation. We should point out that this is a separatist held area. So how challenging will that make establishing the facts here of what exactly happened? Well, it's going to definitely be a bit difficult to really get a concrete war crimes trial with suspects being held in separatist areas at this moment in time, in part because the Russians are going to be engaging in parallel counter-programming of what they believe to be Ukrainian war crimes in the area that will be observed by their friendly countries like Syria, Bolivia and some others.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: But I think it will be possible to ascertain the details of being actually able to punish the suspects concretely.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: It might be harder than it looks. Meanwhile, right now, we're also hearing from Britain's Ministry of Defence reporting that the Wagner Group, so a Russian private military firm, is being used in the east of Ukraine. And if that's correct, what does this tell us about the shape of Russian forces and their strategy as well? Well, it's very interesting to track the role of the Wagner group over the course of time and how much more pronounced and important its role is now compared to what has been at any point in this eight-year conflict, because this conflict began in 2014, not in February of 2022. So originally, they were embedded with the Donetsk and Luhansk separatist militias as like a kind of force multiplier. Then they became an assassin squad against Zelensky, and they carried out atrocities, maybe even involved in the Bucha massacre, according to some German reports.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: Then they became cannon fodder while the Russian forces were resupplying, and now they're on the front lines, in Popazna, Zverodonetsk, and now in the Donetsk Front.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: And that's just a sign of the fact that Russia's running out of trained soldiers, at least from its border force.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: 75,000 have been killed or injured, according to American reports.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: And it's having to rely a lot more on untrained forces, forces that are recruited from the poorest regions of the countries.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: And I wouldn't be surprised down the line, maybe even some foreign fighters popping up in a more concrete way.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Elsewhere today, we've also seen President Zelensky visiting the Odessa region, visiting ports there. Of course, the hope is that Ukrainian grain and grain that's stuck in that port or those ports will soon be out on global markets. But how soon can we expect that? Well, I think it's hard to tell exactly how much.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: I mean, this is a very optimistic sign coming from the Ukrainians today. They said that there were 17 basically containers of grain that were docked in the Black Sea at the time of the invasion. And they've been basically stuck there for a period now of almost six months. So now those grain forces, that grain is coming out. Then there is another ship that's being loaded. And the Ukrainians say that some of this could start being exported by the end of this week. First via Chornomorsk and then probably via Odessa later on.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: So I think the Ukrainians are optimistic of a quick breakthrough here.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: Poland obviously was presenting a much darker and more cynical picture, citing Russia's tendency to violate agreements of any kind.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: And Russia's Odessa port strike over the weekend is a reminder that the Russians can still pull something and make these exports very hard to achieve. All right. Samuel Armani their associate fellow at the Royal United Services Institute joining us from Oxford in the UK. Samuel as ever great to have you with us. Will Europe be hit by a recession. That is the question that economists are asking as inflation across the eurozone hits a record high of 8.9 percent and according to the EU Statistics Office Eurostat the rising cost of energy food industrial goods and services are to blame now the European Central Bank last week announced a hike in interest rates for the first time in 11 years but Eurostat also found that GDP across the eurozone is on the rise with a 0.7% increase seen across the block in the on the rise with a 0.7% increase seen across the block in the second quarter of the year. The European Commissioner for Economy says that while the Union has outperformed expectations, the near-term outlook is still uncertain.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: We can bring in Jacob Kierkegaard now. He's a senior fellow at the German Marshall Fund of the United States and his current research focuses on European economies and structural and institutional reform among many other topics. Welcome to you Jacob. Great to have you with us this evening. So help us understand all of this economic detail. We've got inflation up but we're also seeing GDP growth in the eurozone. So what is the diagnosis then I guess about the health of the eurozone right now. Basically we have a situation of so far so good. We have much stronger growth in the second half of second quarter of the year particularly in southern Europe Spain Italy major upside surprises with the growth over 1 percent. But we still of course have a very significant inflation problem across the INFLATION IS A BIG PROBLEM. WE HAVE A VERY SIGNIFICANT

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: INFLATION PROBLEM ACROSS THE EURO AREA WHICH THE ECB IS ONLY AT THE BEGINNING OF ADDRESSING WITH THE RATE HIKE LAST WEEK.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: AT THE SAME TIME, WE HAVE A MAJOR SOURCE OF UNCERTAINTY ASSOCIATED WITH THE POTENTIAL OF A FULL CUTOFF OF GAS FROM OF THE ECONOMY. WE ARE IN A POSITION OF UNCERTAINTY ASSOCIATED WITH THE POTENTIAL OF A FULL CUTOFF OF GAS FROM RUSSIA. IN SOME WAY, WE HAVE TO WAIT AND SEE. IF THAT DOES NOT MATERIALIZE, IF IN MANY WAYS THE EUROPEAN ECONOMY DOES NOT SUFFER ACUTE ENERGY SHORTAGES, WE MAY WELL AS STILL AVOID A RECESSION. we may well still avoid a recession. I don't think we will avoid a major slowdown. We may very well on the back of these numbers avoid a recession.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: So in light of the inflation numbers in particular should we be anticipating that the European Central Bank actually makes moves particularly in September once again. And do you think that will be enough. Let's say for example if we do see Russia turn off the gas taps.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: say, for example, if we do see Russia turn off the gas taps?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Well, I think with the inflation numbers that we saw, there is very little doubt that the ECB will hike rates probably by another 50 basis points in September. The only question really is what do they do after that? Because that is the point in time in which we will have a much better idea about the gas supply situation for the European economy coming into the winter. And therefore also on whether or not we may or may not need to ration gas for industry etc. in some countries. So excuse me. In that sense you know the the short term interest rate outlook is very clear. But we are still in a situation where ultimately what will tame inflation potentially is the expected growth slowdown in the euro area in the second half of 2022. Briefly Jacob if you don't mind are there any countries which are looking a little bit more concerning than others right now. Well I don't think there's any doubt that the flat growth in Germany already in the second quarter is a cause of concern because we know that Germany is one of the countries that have to reduce domestic demand for gas the most. It is one of the countries that is most exposed to potential rationing of gas for heavy industrial use. And therefore, I think in that sense, Germany, of all the European, the euro area members, are probably the one looking most likely to experience a contraction in the economy in the second half.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: All right, Germany then, the country to watch for now.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Jacob Kierkegaard, senior fellow at the German Marshall Fund of the United States.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Great to have your insights.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Thank you.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Romania will not abandon the Republic of Moldova.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: That was the message at a meeting between the country's two presidents in Bucharest earlier today.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Yesterday, Moldova's parliament voted to extend a state of emergency as the country struggles to cope with the impact of the war in Ukraine, including a wave of refugees, inflation and an energy crisis.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Christy Citra from our sister station, Euronews Romania, has more on the story now.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: This is the first official visit of President Maia Sandu after the European Union granted the Republic of Moldova the candidate country status last month.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: The desperate energy situation of Moldova was one of the main points on the agenda during the high-level discussions in Bucharest.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: Maia Sandu emphasized that her country urgently needs natural gas from Romania to keep the economy going and to preserve social stability.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: She said that gas and energy prices have soared in the Republic of Moldova as the only gas supplier of the country at this time is Russia.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: Romanian President Klaus Iohannis assured Maia Sandu that Romania would not abandon the Republic of Moldova. He promised to expedite the works on the gas pipeline that would allow the gas delivery across the Prut River at the border between two countries and to interconnect the electricity networks between Romania and the Republic of Moldova.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Well, still to come, the Commonwealth Games is in full swing in the UK, and this year's event features more women's and para sports than ever before. Stay with us. GAMES IS IN FULL SWING IN THE U.K. AND THIS YEAR'S EVENT FEATURES MORE WOMEN'S AND PARA SPORTS THAN EVER BEFORE. STAY WITH US.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: YOU'RE WATCHING EURO NEWS TONIGHT. WELCOME BACK.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: AS EUROPE FACES A GROWING NATURAL GAS CRISIS, IT IS URGENTLY LOOKING FOR WAYS TO SAVE ON ENERGY IN CASE RUSSIA TURNS OFF THE TAPS.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: EU ENERGY MINISTERS THIS WEEK AGREED TO VOLUNTARILY CUT GAS USAGE ACROSS THE BLOCK BY 15% IN THE RUN-UP TO WINTER. off the taps. Well, EU energy ministers this week agreed to voluntarily cut gas usage across the block by 15% in the run-up to winter, and now member states are trying to find ways to meet that goal. Well, in Spain, Prime Minister Pedro Sanchez has called on public officials to stop wearing ties in a bid to stay cool instead of relying on air conditioning. Elsewhere, the German city of Hanover will cut off hot water in gyms, swimming pools and public buildings. It will also ban mobile air conditioning units and radiators. German authorities also say that they will impose a gas tax to cover the cost of replacing Russian supplies and prevent energy companies from going bankrupt. For more on this, we can bring in Kristina Jovanovsky now in Berlin. Kristina, I guess winter might feel quite a way off for people enjoying the warm German summer right now. But of course the government is making plans. And as I understand it it will affect household budgets. Yeah absolutely. That's what we're being told by the government. This levy will be applied to gas consumers across the country including two households. We're expecting hundreds of euros extra a year that households will be applied to gas consumers across the country, including to households.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: We're expecting hundreds of euros extra a year that households will be having to pay for this gas levy.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: The idea is that consumers and individuals and companies will be sharing in the cost of decreasing Germany's reliance on rushing gas.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: It was last year, 55% of gas imports.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: It's now down to about one-third of gas imports for Germany.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Last week, a company had to get a bailout from the German government.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: So there is major concerns about the economy and for companies.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: For a household of four people, we're told that their price would be about 500 euros extra a year, but it could even go up to 1,000 euros. This levy is expected to be applied in August and last at least until September next year. And we are expecting to get more details about this draft law in August, but we're already feeling some of that limitation. Nord Stream 1, the gas pipeline from Russia, had decreased its capacity to 20% already. So we know that there's going to be major issues in the winter. And Christina, in anticipation of that, we've got some German cities that have decided just not to wait. They're already rolling out measures in order to save energy where they can. Tell us about some of those initiatives. Right. So some local smaller areas had started in our scene hand over the first major city doing stronger measures such as limiting hot water. It's not provide hot water and public buildings for hand washing as well as no hot water for showers at pools and gyms and sports halls.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: They're also not lighting up buildings as they usually would or not using fountains.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: One local official had said that he's hoping that this sends a message that Germany cannot be hurt that badly by the limit on Russian gas supply. And therefore, it will send a message to Russian President Vladimir Putin that he should focus his focus on something else that's not gas supply for Germany.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Berlin had also implemented similar measures or decided to do so in the spring that it would decrease the temperature of pools in the springtime to make them a bit colder. I was at one this week. It wasn't too bad. It wasn't warm, but it wasn't that cold either. And it didn't seem like it was decreasing the popularity. There was literally hundreds of people there and a lot of children. It seems to be they seem to be having fun. So it didn't seem too bad. But there does seem to be some possibly more drastic measures.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Some officials are saying that possibly they should consider having Oktoberfest or even Christmas markets cancelled to save on energy.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: All right, Cristina Jovanovski there reporting from Berlin.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Cristina, thanks for that.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: A Spanish artist has come under fire after using materials they didn't have the rights to in a recent poster campaign our team in the cube has been looking at it. Well Helena today's story is about a rather magnificent fall from grace two days ago the Spanish Ministry of Equality released this campaign called Summer is also ours and so initially it received quite a lot of positive feedback notably for normalizing different body shapes and fighting fat phobia but in the space of a few hours this campaign went from universal acclaim to global disdain we're not going to show you the full campaign because of all of the issues behind it the first one is that one of the models on the image behind me, her name is Naomi Nicholas Williams, she took to social media to explain that basically one of her personal images on Instagram was taken and used on this poster without her permission.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: And what's even more bizarre is that her face was taken and photoshopped on the body of someone else.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: And something similar happened to another model in this poster, Raissa Galvao, who had her body used, but then her face was modified with the artist adding shorter hair and sunglasses.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: But that's not all.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Another one of the controversy of this poster is also the typography that was used. A Twitter user said that he knew the designer that did this typeface and that he had not been paid for it. Now the artist that did this campaign has come out on Twitter to apologize saying that I apologize to the models for having been inspired by their photographs for the campaign and for having used an unlicensed typeface without knowing that it was not free. And she also promised that she will share part of the profits equally with all the models as well as the designer that are concerned. And so the Women's Institute, an organization under the Ministry of Equality that commissioned this work, has released a statement thanking the artist for recognizing the error regarding the illustration and to being open to listening to the woman involved in the fight against fatphobia and racism.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: But Helena, not everyone on the internet is convinced.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: The campaign was initially meant to fight violence, aesthetic violence, but some Twitter users like this one argued that without asking for their consent, these women have been subjected to another type of violence, this time an economic one.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Sophia, as you say, quite a fall from grace for a campaign that was meant to be about body positivity. Sophia, thanks a lot.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Well there is plenty of sporting action getting underway in the UK's second largest city of Birmingham as day one of the 2022 Commonwealth Games kicks off. Now, reigning Olympic, world and Commonwealth champion Flora Duffy bagged herself a gold medal in the women's triathlon, and England's Alex Lee secured the top spot on the podium in the men's. Now, over 5,000 athletes representing 72 nations will be vying for podium positions over the next 11 days.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Among the 280 medal events, there's some new additions.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: We've got women's 220 cricket and three-on-three basketball making their debut.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: This year's Games features a record number of events for women and para-sport athletes.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Meanwhile, some extraordinary women have been powering through eastern France in stage six of the Tour de France Femme.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Dutch rider Marine Vos sprinted to victory in Rosheim, winning by just a bike's length.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: The 35-year-old has now extended her lead over Silvia Pesico on the general classification.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Plenty more coming up after a short break.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Don't go anywhere.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: You're watching Euronews tonight.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: Welcome back to the programme.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: As the war in Ukraine rages on, many Russian citizens looking for a summer break are travelling to Finland, but now some Finnish politicians and residents say that the influx of tourists is a cause for concern, as Richard Cady reports.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: Buses of Russian tourists stream into Finland at the Noyama border crossing in the country's southeast, some hoping to enjoy the peaceful Finnish summer and others planning to travel further into Europe. But many Finns are unhappy with the situation and the thought of Russians enjoying a Finnish summer while Ukrainians suffer under a brutal invasion has been met with indignation.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Ukrainian citizens are being killed, civilians, women and children in Ukraine. And then on the other hand, Russian citizens are on holiday in the EU. I think that this is an unbearable situation.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: As an act of solidarity with Ukraine, Finland's Conservative opposition party proposed a halt to new tourist visas for Russians this week. The policy appears to have parliamentary backing, but for some Russian tourists are an important source of income for Finnish border towns. I think this is the the most absurd idea which they have because I mean what what they gain from isolating the normal Russian citizens who doesn't have any anything to do with the decision with the political decisions of the of the leaders in in Russia. Russia lifted COVID travel restrictions on July 15th.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: Consequently Russian tourists heading to Finland has steadily increased. But this may soon change.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: I'll be very, very sad and disappointed because I really like Finland and I like resting here. And this is a wonderful country and nature and lakes and I'll be disappointed.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: wonderful country and nature and lakes and I will be disappointed. Finland issued over 10,000 new visas to Russians in July according to local media reports and this is in addition to the hundred thousand existing visas which makes imposing travel restrictions more complicated.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: You're up to date. Thanks for your company. Bye for now.
